Creation of silanol nests on HZSM-5 catalyst to boost the alkylation of toluene with methanol for PX synthesis Guoqiang Hou Methodology Data curation Writing – original draft a 1 Tingjun Fu Conceptualization Investigation Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ 1 Xin Li b Qian Ma a Zhong Li Conceptualization Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Coal Science and Technology of Ministry of Education and Shanxi Province, Institute of Coal Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, Shanxi, China Key Laboratory of Coal Science and Technology of Ministry of Education and Shanxi Province, Institute of Coal Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan Shanxi 030024 China Key Laboratory of Coal Science and Technology of Ministry of Education and Shanxi Province, Institute of Coal Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, 030024, Shanxi, China b SINOPEC Research Institute of Petroleum Processing, State Key Laboratory of Catalytic Materials and Reaction Engineering for Petrochemical Industry, Beijing 100083, China SINOPEC Research Institute of Petroleum Processing, State Key Laboratory of Catalytic Materials and Reaction Engineering for Petrochemical Industry Beijing 100083 China SINOPEC Research Institute of Petroleum Processing, State Key Laboratory of Catalytic Materials and Reaction Engineering for Petrochemical Industry, Beijing 100083, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These two authors contribute equally in this work. HZSM-5 catalysts with abundant silanol nests were fabricated by removing framework Al, which effectively promoted the selective alkylation of toluene with methanol by inhibiting the deep alkylation of aromatics to heavy aromatics and the conversion of methanol to light hydrocarbons. Correspondingly, the alkylation efficiency reached 65.3% at a toluene conversion of 31.3% over dealuminated HZSM-5, higher than the 55.2% efficiency and 28.0% conversion of parent zeolites, respectively. In situ DRIFTS and single-factor experimental clarified that toluene adsorption was enhanced and methanol to hydrocarbons was inhibited with the presence of silanol nests. Additionally, by increasing the crystal size of HZSM-5 with silanol nests from 2 to 5 µm, para-xylene selectivity was increased from 36.1% to 65.5% because of the enhanced diffusion barrier. The finding of the positive effect of the silanol nests on toluene alkylation can provide a solid fundamental basis for the rational design of catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Toluene alkylation with methanol HZSM-5 Silanol nests Methanol-to-hydrocarbon reactions Para-xylene 1 Introduction As an important raw chemical material, para-xylene (PX) is mainly used for the synthesis of terephthalic acid and terephthalates for the production of polyester [1–3]. The rapidly growing demand for polyesters boomed the market and over 50 million tons of PX had been consumed around the world in 2020 [2]. Currently, the PX production mainly depends upon petroleum routes, including catalytic reforming, isomerization of C8 aromatics, toluene disproportionation and alkylation transfer. However, owing to the similar boiling point of xylene and ethylbenzene, the separation and purification of PX from the mixtures of xylene isomers and ethylbenzene was difficult and required high energy and cost [4]. In contrast, the methylation of toluene with methanol under the shape-selective catalytic effect of zeolite catalyst could get the PX product with higher selectivity, which had attracted extensive attention in academia and industry due to its efficiency and economy [4–6]. However, several side reactions inevitably presented in the methylation of toluene with methanol, such as methanol to hydrocarbons (MTH), deep alkylation and isomerization, which decreased the efficient conversion of toluene and effective utilization of methanol for methylation [7,8]. HZSM-5 is considered as one of the most effective catalysts for toluene methylation with methanol for its high catalytic activity and excellent shape-selective nature [9]. However, excessive strong acid sites over HZSM-5 could promote the aromatics-based cycle and alkenes-based cycle process with methanol participation, leading to the transformation of methoxonium ions into olefins and heavy aromatics, which significantly decreased the utilization of methoxonium ions for toluene alkylation and also accelerated deactivation of catalyst [10]. Not only that, toluene adsorption was quite weak over HZSM-5 with excessive strong acid sites, which was detrimental to the further toluene conversion. In addition, the isomerization reaction of PX on external surface acid sites could decrease the PX selectivity and should be suppressed to avoid the further transformation of PX [11,12]. Thus, the fine regulation of the acidic properties of zeolite was required to inhibit the MTH reactions and enhance the toluene adsorption to promote the efficient alkylation conversion of toluene. Promoter modification could regulate the acidic property of HZSM-5 catalysts and decrease the pore size for selective diffusion of products simultaneously. The introduced P compounds could react with Al on bridged hydroxyl groups to form Al-P-O in the HZSM-5 channels. Strong acid sites were reduced and the diffusion barriers of MX and OX were increased, which increased PX selectivity from 30.7% to 97% [13]. Boron modification could also decrease the strong acid sites and narrow the pore opening by forming the B-O-Si bond in the interior part of HZSM-5. As a result, isomerization of PX was prevented and the selectivity of PX was increased from 52% to 99%. Boron could be converted into boric acid during the reaction and easily migrated out of the catalyst, which induced the deactivation of the catalyst [14]. Similarly, Mg and Zn introduction could convert Brønsted acid sites into Lewis acid sites by substituting protons on the hydroxyl group with metal ions. Take Mg2+ modifiers an example, Mg modifications could increase Lewis acid sits by creating Mg(OH)+ at the expense of Brønsted acid sites on the micropore surface. It should be noted that, MgO clusters could also be formed especially under high loading and could narrow the pore openings, which increased the PX selectivity from 25% to 80% because of the regulated acidity and the enhanced shape-selective nature of the zeolite channel. Modifications with more than one promoter could obtain a comprehensive optimistic effect by eliminating external surface acid sites, regulating the acid property and simultaneously narrowing the pore opening [15,16]. For example, the simultaneous P and Mg modifications could effectively neutralize Brønsted acid sites of HZSM-5 and narrow pore openings. P species and Mg species could react with each other to form magnesium phosphate under water vapor atmosphere, restraining the loss of Mg species. The multi-modified catalyst was reported to have high para-selectivity (~98%) and catalytic stability [17]. To eliminate the external acid sites, chemical liquid deposition of SiO2 was used to create acid-free surface SiO2 layers and the selectivity of PX was increased from 25% to 96.2% after four cycles of the silica deposition process [18]. However, the specific surface area decreased from 329 to 271 m2/g after the silica deposition because some of the micropores were blocked. The inhibited pore diffusion decreased the toluene conversion from 48.6% to 27% [18]. In contrast, epitaxial growth of silicalite-1 along with HZSM-5 not only covered the external surface acid sites but also basically reserved the pore structure of parent zeolite [4,9,19]. The PX selectivity was increased from 45% to 88% with toluene conversion unchanged over ZSM-5 @silicalite-1 [4]. Despite these efforts, developing suitable methods to inhibit the MTH reaction and to improve the selective methylation of toluene with methanol remains a significant challenge. Interestingly, toluene alkylation with methanol could be catalyzed by silanol nests on aluminum-free silicalite-1 (S-1), as found by Zhang et al. [21]. However, the low density of silanol groups limited the catalytic activity of S-1 and the catalytic mechanism of silanol groups for toluene methylation with methanol has not been clear yet. In this work, high SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 =300,1000) were treated with 1 M nitric acid solution to create silanol nests by removing part of the framework Al. The textural and acidity properties of ZSM-5 were studied through XRD, TEM, ICP, N2 adsorption-desorption, 27Al MAS NMR, NH3-TPD, and Py-FTIR. Especially, the information of silanol nests with hydrogen bonds created by dealumination was characterized by 1H MAS NMR and OH-FTIR. The effects of silanol nests on the catalytic performance of toluene and methanol were also systematically investigated. The reaction behaviors of methanol and toluene were tracked using the in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS). It was found that the created silanol nests significantly changed the reaction behavior of methanol and enhanced the adsorption of toluene, which were key factors to improve the catalytic performance (toluene conversion and alkylation efficiency). This work provides a new insight into toluene methylation with methanol catalyzed by silanol nests and provides a new idea for the preparation of high-performance alkylation catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation methods All chemicals and gas used for the present research were obtained by commercial route, including aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3.9 H2O, 99.0 wt%, Tianjin Kemeiou Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 98.0 wt%, Tianjin Kemeiou Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd), ammonium chloride (NH4Cl, 99.0 wt%, Tianjin Kemeiou Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd), Tetrapropylammonium bromide (TPABr, 98.0 wt%, Aladdin Co. Ltd), silica sol (30%), Ammonium fluosilicate (H8F6N2Si, 98.0 wt%, Aladdin Co. Ltd), methanol (CH3OH, 99.5 wt%, Tianjin Kemeiou Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd), toluene (C7H8, 99.0 wt%, Tianjin Shentai Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd) and nitrogen (N2, 99 wt%, Taiyuan Iron&Steel Co. Ltd). HZSM-5 zeolite with SiO2/Al2O3 ratios of 300 and 1000 were synthesized based on the previously reported method [20]. In a typical synthesis, sodium hydroxide and tetrapropylammonium bromide were firstly dissolved into deionized water, followed by adding silica sol and stirring at 80 °C for 6 h. Next, aluminum nitrate was added and kept stirring for 1 h to obtain the gel with the molar composition of 0.8 Na2O: 0.8TPABr: 10SiO2: 200 H2O: xAl2O3 (x = 0.033 and 0.01). The obtained gel was transferred into stainless-steel autoclaves for crystallization at 170 °C for 16 h. The resultant samples were filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 100 °C overnight, and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h to remove the template. Finally, the synthesized samples were ion-exchange three times in 0.8 M NH4Cl solution (solid-to-liquid ratio was 1:20) at 80 °C for 3 h, followed by filtering, washing, and calcining at 550 °C for 6 h. The obtained HZSM-5 samples were named as H300 and H1000. Based on the above procedure, the aging time was shortened to 1 h and the crystallization time was increased to 120 h for the synthesis of large HZSM-5 crystals with 5 µm. The obtained samples were named as H1000-L after ion-exchange with 0.8 M NH4Cl. Silicalite-1(S-1) with crystal size of 2 µm was prepared by using a similar procedure as the synthesis of ZSM-5. Typically, sodium hydroxide and tetrapropylammonium bromide were dissolved into deionized water, followed by adding silica sol and stirring at 80 °C for 7 h; The well-mixed gel with a molar composition of 0.8 Na2O: 0.8TPABr: 10SiO2: 200 H2O was transferred into stainless-steel autoclaves for crystallization at 170 °C for 16 h. The resultant samples were filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 100 °C overnight, and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h to remove the template. Finally, the synthesized silicalite-1 sample was ion-exchange three times in 0.8 M NH4Cl solution (solid-to-liquid ratio was 1:20) at 80 °C for 3 h, followed by filtering, washing and calcining at 550 °C for 6 h. The obtained silicalite-1 was named as HS-1. To create a high density of silanol nests on ZSM-5, the above synthesized Na form ZSM-5 samples were dealuminated with 1 M nitric acid solution (solid-to-liquid ratio was 1:20) under continuous stirring at 100 °C for 3 h for three times. After acid treatment, the sample was washed with deionized water until the filtrate pH was close to 7 and then dried at 100 °C overnight. After ion-exchanged treatment with 0.8 M NH4Cl solution as mentioned above, the obtained samples were named as HDA300, HDA1000 and HDA1000-L. According to the reported method, HZSM-5(SiO2/Al2O3 =1000) with few of silanol nests could be obtained by defect-repairing treatment [21]. This treatment was carried out at 90 °C for 16 h using 0.01 M (NH4)2SiF6 solution (solid-to-liquid ratio was 1:20). After treatment, the obtained samples were washed with deionized water, dried at 100 °C overnight, ion-exchanged with 0.8 M NH4Cl solution, and finally calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. The obtained samples were named as HDA1000-R. Additionally, dealuminated NaDA1000 without ion-exchange was also used to support the role of silanol nests. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The HZSM-5 zeolite samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) with Cu Kα (λ = 1.541862 nm, 40 kV, 100 mA) at a scanning rate of 20 min−1 in the 2θ range of 5.0–50.0◦ by a Rigaku D/Max 2500. The morphology of zeolite samples was measured by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images on a JEM-2100 F instrument operated at 200 kV. The TEM samples were prepared by steeping ethanol solution of the sample on a carbon-coated copper grid and drying under ambient temperature conditions. High-resolution SEM images were taken with a JSM-7001 F (2.0 kV, in a gentle-beam mode) without a metal coating. The pore volume and surface area were measured by nitrogen adsorption on a Beishide 3 H-2000PS2 instrument at − 196 °C. The samples were pretreated at 250 °C for 4 h before measurement. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was applied to calculate the isotherm and the T-Plot method was used to calculate the pore volume. The pore size distribution of zeolites was calculated based on BJH method. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was performed on a Rigaku ZSX Primus II fluorescence spectrometer and Optima 2100 DV optical emission spectrometer from Perkin Elmer, respectively, to determine the Si/Al ratio in samples. The acid properties of ZSM-5 zeolites were analyzed by Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD). NH3-TPD profiles were collected by a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 apparatus. Typically, 0.1 g sample was placed into a quartz U- type tube, preheated in a flow of He 1 h, followed by full exposure in 5 vol% NH3-He gas. After being purged with He, TPD was finally run from 120 °C to 600 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C per minute. Py-FTIR spectra were measured on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer to record the concentration of different types of acid sites at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The samples were pressed into a self-supporting wafer which was prepared using 20 mg HZSM-5 samples. The diameter of wafer was ~13 mm. Then the wafer was placed in a cell pretreated at 400 °C for 1.5 h under vacuum (10−3). Next, the sample was exposed to pyridine at room temperature for 0.5 h and evacuated at 400 °C for 1 h. The spectrum was recorded at room temperature. The calculation method of Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites were based on the following equations: C pyridine on B sites = 1.88 IA B × R 2 / w C pyridine on L sites = 1.42 IA L × R 2 / w Where C represents the concentration of Brønsted acid sites (B) or Lewis acid sites (L), IA (B, L) was the integrated absorbance of B or L band, R was the radius of catalyst disk and W was the mass of disk. FTIR spectra in the OH-stretch region of samples were also measured by Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer using transmission mode at a resolution 4 cm−1. In a typical procedure, HZSM-5 samples were pressed into 30 mg self-supporting wafer, which was prepared by zeolite sample mixed with KBr (the mass ratio of samples and KBr=1/100), and pretreated at 400 °C for 4 h under vacuum (10−4 Pa). After pretreatment, the cell was cool down to 30 °C for spectrum recording. The background spectrum was recorded with a pure KBr wafer under the same procedures. The 27Al MAS NMR experiments were performed on a 600 MHz Bruker Avance III nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer. Before the test, the ZSM-5 samples were placed in a closed container with saturated KCl solution and hydrated at room temperature for 10 h. Then, the 27Al MAS NMR spectra were obtained at a spinning rate of 13 kHz using a π/12 pulse width of 1.2 μs and a recycle delay of 1 s by scanning 1 × 104 times. 1H MAS NMR experiments were recorded on a Agilent 600 DD2 spectrometer operating at a Larmor frequency of 600 MHz. Before experiment, all samples were pretreated at 400 °C for 4 h under dry air atmosphere. 1H magic angle spinning (MAS) NMR spectra employed a 4.0 mm double resonance 1 H-X MAS probe and a spinning frequency of 10.0 kHz. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy measurements (In situ DRIFTS) were performed on Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer at ambient pressure. Firstly, 10 mg zeolite samples were placed in the cell and heated to 400 °C for 30 min at the 10 mL min−1 of nitrogen atmosphere. The background spectrum was recorded with zeolite samples before reaction under the same condition at 400 °C. The reactant stream was induced by inletting reaction gases into a Monteggia washing bottle at room temperature. The spectrum was recorded at 10-second intervals. 2.3 Alkylation of toluene and methanol performance evaluation The alkylation of toluene and methanol was performed in a fixed-bed reactor with a stainless steel tube at 460 °C under atmospheric pressure. In each run, 0.8 g catalyst（80–100 mesh）was well mixed with 1.6 g quartz sands and packed into the middle of the reactor. Before reaction, the catalyst sample was pretreated in a nitrogen stream of 35 mL min−1 at 500 °C for 1 h. A mixture toluene and methanol with 2:1 molar ratio was pumped into the reactor at WHSV= 4 h−1 when the temperature was decreased to 460 °C. The oil phase products were analyzed by Zhongkehuifen GC-7820A instrument equipped with FID detector. The gas product and unreacted methanol was analyzed by Zhongkehuifen GC-7820 instrument equipped with FID and TCD detector. The selectivity of PX was calculated by PX in xylene and the selectivity of light hydrocarbons were calculated by the light hydrocarbons in gas products.The conversion of toluene and methanol, the distribution of production, the selectively alkylated methanol was calculated by the following equations. The conversion of toluene = N toluene in - N toluene out N toluene in × 100 % The conversion of methanol = N m ethanol in − N methanol out N methanol in × 100 % Fraction of methanol for toluene methylation = N xylene out - 2 ×N benzene out N methanol in - N methanol out × 100 % Fraction of methanol for xylene methylation = 2 ×N trimethylbenzene out N methanol in - N methanol out × 100 % Fraction of methanol for TMB methylation = 3 × N Tetramethylbenzene out N methanol in - N methanol out × 100 % Alkylation efficiency = N xylene out - 2 ×N benzene out + 2 × N trimethylbenzene out + 3 × N Tetramethylbenzene out N methanol in - N methanol out × 100 % Where N X in and N X out are the molars of X at the inlet and outlet. The product distribution and the selectivity PX in xylene were calculated using molar percentage of the product. Space − time yield of PX = W PX W cat ×t Where W PX represents the mass of PX obtained from the reaction, W cat was the mass of catalyst and t was reaction time. All catalytic performance data were based on TOS = 20 h reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural and structural properties of zeolite Fig. 1a presents the XRD patterns of the synthesized parent and dealuminated HZSM-5. The parent HZSM-5 exhibited the typical characteristic peaks of the MFI structure in the 2θ= 7°− 10° and 22°− 25° ranges[22]. The dealuminated samples had characteristic diffraction peaks that were similar to the parent zeolites, reflecting that the dealumination had a negligible impact on the zeolite framework structure. The referential HS-1 was also synthesized successfully, as confirmed by the XRD result. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms in Fig. 1b demonstrate that all samples possessed Type I adsorption isotherms with a hysteresis loop of H4, indicating the micropore characteristic according to the IUPAC classification [23]. The nitrogen uptake at P/P0 = 0.4–0.8 was caused by the intergranular porosity formed by the twin crystal structure of the zeolite [24]. Table 1 shows that H300 and H1000 had similar BET surface area and pore volume. For HDA300 and HDA1000, the framework was partially damaged by dealumination, slightly decreasing the total micropore volume and generated larger micropores (Table 1). A more significant decrease in the textural properties could be observed over H1000–L after dealumination. The BET surface area and micropore volume were decreased from 357 to 177 m2 g−1 and from 0.15 to 0.06 cm3 g−1, respectively (Table 1 and Fig. S1). This was probably because that the extracted Al and Si species were more difficult to diffuse out of the long channels of the large HZSM-5 crystal, which could significantly block the microporous channels [25]. The ICP-OES results in Fig. 1d and Table 2 show that the SiO2/Al2O3 ratios of dealuminated HZSM-5 were obviously increased compared with their parent samples, indicating that part of aluminum atoms was successfully removed during acid treatment. Since it was difficult to remove the framework Al of HZSM-5 with higher SiO2/Al2O3 ratio, a less reduction in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio over H1000 was found. The TEM and SEM images in Fig. 2 shows that the crystal size of H300 and H1000 are uniformly distributed in 1.9–2.1 µm with a high intergrowth morphology. Furthermore, the morphology of dealuminated samples was not changed, suggesting that the structure of HZSM-5 was not severely damaged during dealumination. 3.2 Acidic properties of the catalysts The differences in acidic properties between the parent and dealuminated catalysts were analyzed by NH3–TPD. As shown in Fig. 3, the desorption curves of all tested samples were fitted into three peak, which corresponded to the ammonia desorption from the weak, mid-strong, and strong acid sites from low to high temperature [26]. The quantitative calculation results show that the total amount of acid sites decreased from 237.1 to 97.5 µmol g−1 as the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio increased from 300 to 1000 for parent zeolites. After removing the partial framework Al using a nitric acid solution, the total amount of acid sites decreased from 237.1 µmol g−1 of H300 to 159.1 µmol g−1 of HDA300 and the strong acid sites reduced from 129.1 to 62.1 µmol g−1, while some new mid-strong acid sites were generated during acid treatment and the amount of mid-strong acid sites increased from 54.0 to 74.0 µmol g−1 [27,28]. Similarly, H1000 also exhibited a decrease in the strong acid sites from 42.3 to 33.0 µmol g−1 and well-maintained mid-strong acid sites after dealumination ( Table 3). Furthermore, the reference sample HS-1 had very low acidity, which was attributed to the absence of Al in HS-1. As shown in the Py-FTIR spectra (Fig. 3f), two adsorption bands at 1550 and 1450 cm−1 were found for the two-parent HZSM-5, which were assigned to the pyridinium bound to the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively [29]. After dealumination, the intensities of the two adsorption bands were significantly reduced, indicating the reduction of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. As the results listed in Table 3, the amount of Brønsted acid sites of H300 decreased from 17.0 to 0.5 µmol g−1, while that of Lewis acid sites decreased from 16.0 to 11.5 µmol g−1. For H1000, Brønsted acid sites decreased from 10.0 to 0.7 µmol g−1 and the Lewis acid sites decreased from 14.0 to 8.3 µmol g−1. The lower densities of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites suggested that both the framework aluminum and the extra-framework aluminum were removed during acid treatment. Considering that the extra-framework aluminum could be preferentially removed, the well-maintained Lewis acid sites were formed by the electropositive hydrogen atoms of the silanol nests, not by the extra-framework aluminum [30–32]. This result could also be supported by the acidic properties of Al-free HS-1 with only the Lewis acid sites. The Al state was characterized using 27Al MAS NMR. Herein, H1000 was taken as an example to illustrate the changes in Al state during acid treatment. As shown in Fig. 4, the peaks located at 49–59 ppm and 0 ppm were assigned to the framework (AlF) and extra-framework Al species (AlEF) respectively [33]. The peak corresponding to AlF was further fitted into four peaks at 49, 53, 56 and 59 ppm, where the peak at 49, 53 and 59 ppm was assigned to AlF located at channel intersections and 56 ppm was assigned to AlF located at the straight channels [34]. After the dealumination process, the relative peak area at 56 ppm and 0 ppm of HDA1000 were significantly decreased from 40.79% to 37.68% and decreased from 1.68% to 1.45% respectively, which indicated that the AlF located at the straight 10-MR channels and AlEF were removed during the acid treatment ( Table 4). The OH structure in the dealuminated HZSM-5 catalyst was investigated by OH-FTIR. In Fig. 5, three typical bands were observed in the 3800-–3000 cm−1 region. The first band is centered at 3500 cm−1, which could be ascribed to the silanol nests with a hydrogen bond, consisting of several silanol groups. The second band typically at 3600 cm−1 is assigned to the Brønsted acid sites formed by the OH group located between the Si and Al atoms in the zeolite framework [Si(OH)Al]. The third band at 3745 cm−1 is associated with the isolated silanol [22,35,36]. For H300 and H1000, clear absorption band at 3600 cm−1 indicated the presence of the Brønsted acid sites. Compared with the parent H300, HDA300 presented a new stronger absorption band at 3500 cm−1 (silanol nests) but a weaker absorption band at 3600 cm−1 [Si(OH)Al]. This indicated that certain Brønsted acid sites were removed, simultaneously creating silanol nests (Fig. S2). Similar changes in the absorption bands were also found for HDA1000 after acid treatment, indicating the transformation of some Si(OH)Al into silanol nests during dealumination. 1H MAS NMR spectras were used to quantitatively investigate the silanol groups of the HZSM-5. Chemical shifts at 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0–5.0 ppm were respectively attributed to external isolated Si-OH, internal isolated Si-OH and silanol nests with hydrogen bonds [32,37]. And Si(OH)Al could be assigned to the broadband at 5.3–6.0 ppm [37]. For parent HZSM-5 zeolite, because of the less Si(OH)Al on H1000, the adsorption peak of 1H MAS NMR spectra was shifted from 5.2 ppm of H300 to 4.6 ppm of H1000 ( Fig. 6). After dealumination, the absorption peaks were shifted to lower chemical shifts (5.2 vs. 4.3 ppm for HDA300, 4.6 vs. 4.5 ppm for HDA1000) and the corresponding percentage of silanol nests was increased clearly. For instance, the percentage of silanol nests for HDA1000 was increased to 86.3% ( Table 5), higher than 42.7% for H1000. These results also suggested that Si(OH)Al was transformed into silanol nests after acid treatment [32] (Fig. 6). 3.3 Toluene alkylation with methanol 3.3.1 Catalytic performance of parent zeolites The catalytic performances of the two parent samples were evaluated firstly ( Fig. 7). For H300, the toluene conversion reached 28.0% with a PX selectivity of 25.1% at 20 h reaction. As the reaction progressed, the PX selectivity was gradually increased to 27.4% because of the covered external acid sites and the narrowed pore openings induced by the coke deposition. Additionally, 16.0% C9+ aromatics ( Table 6), 51.3% ethylene and 26.6% propylene selectivity were also obtained at 20 h reaction over H300 (Table S1). Deep alkylation (e.g., xylenes to TriMBs and TetraMBs) was known to generate C9+ aromatics, and light hydrocarbons were primarily produced from the MTH process. In this work, the high acidity density of H300 promoted the deep alkylation and the MTH process [7,8]. Therefore, the fraction of methanol used for toluene alkylation to xylene was only 39.1%. In contrast, in case of H1000 with a low acidity density, the toluene conversion was 24.3% and the PX selectivity could reach 27.8% at 20 h reaction (Table 6). Not only that, the deep alkylation and the light hydrocarbons formation were also decreased under this low the acidity density, which increased the utilization of methanol for the toluene alkylation to 46.9%. Unlike H300 and H1000, the HS-1 acidity was quite weak, and no Brønsted acid sites were found (Table 3 and Fig. S4). However, the toluene conversion still reached 29.4%, owning to the decreased deep alkylation and light hydrocarbons formation under weak acidity. This intensified selective alkylation of toluene and methanol could also be reflected by the decreased C9+ aromatic selectivity (13.8%) and the increased methanol fraction for xylene (47.4%) (Table 6). In addition, the PX selectivity was well kept at 30.5% during the reaction, which was mainly determined by its fewer external acid sites. 3.3.2 Catalytic performance of dealuminated HZSM-5 The improved catalytic performance was obtained for dealuminated HZSM-5 compared with the parent sample. Over HDA1000, the maximum toluene conversion could reach 31.3%, which is higher than 24.3% of H1000 ( Fig. 8a). C9+ aromatics selectivity was only 11.5%, and ethylene and propylene selectivity were 44.9% and 23.9% respectively, significantly lower than those of H1000 (Fig. S3). These improved results could be attributed to the decreased deep alkylation and the weakened MTH reaction after the fabrication of silanol nests with weak acidity (Fig. 8d,e). In addition, the increased fraction of methanol used for xylene over HDA1000 (from 46.9% to 51.4%) directly revealed the increased selective alkylation of toluene and methanol. It's worth noting that due to the blockage of micropores and the removal of external surface acid sites during the dealumination, the PX selectivity over HDA1000 was increased from 27.8% of H300 to 36.1% [38,39]. Correspondingly, the space-time yield of PX over HDA1000 reached 337.8 mg·gcat −1·h−1, much higher than 250.2 mg·gcat −1·h−1 of H1000 (Table 6). Similarly, dealumination over HA300 also created silanol nests with weak acidity for HDA300 and promoted the selective alkylation of toluene and methanol. 30.4% toluene conversion and 51.7% PX selectivity were achieved over HDA300, much higher than those of parent H300. However, a rapid deactivation occurred for HDA300 due to the severe damage to the microporous structure during dealumination (Table 6 and Fig S5). 3.4 Discussions In toluene methylation with methanol, more methanol participation in the alkylation could increase the toluene conversion. In this work, silanol nests with weak Lewis acidity were fabricated for HZSM-5 by dealumination, which increased methanol participation in alkylation with toluene and promoted the conversion of toluene ( Fig. 9a and Fig S6). For instance, the fraction of methanol for xylene was increased from 46.9% to 51.3% and corresponding toluene conversion increased from 24.3% to 31.3% for HDA1000, as the percentage of the Lewis acid sites increased from 58% to 92% after the dealumination process. Herein, the formation of silanol nests was at the expense of Brønsted acid sites. So, the creation of silanol nests inevitably decreased Brønsted acid sites, which could decrease the deep alkylation as reflected by the linear correlation between C9+ aromatics selectivity and the amount of Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 9b). The decreased C9+ aromatics after introducing silanol nests could inhibit the aromatic cycle and reduce the formation of ethylene, which could be observed from the relationship between the selectivity of ethylene and the C9+ aromatics selectivity (Fig. 9c). From the perspective of the dual-cycle mechanism of methanol to hydrocarbons, the reduction of ethylene could further inhibit the olefin cycle, which could also decrease the formation of propylene [40,41]. Additionally, the linear correlation between the percentage of silanol nests and xylene selectivity also verified the positive effect of the fabrication of silanol nests on selective alkylation of toluene (Fig. 9d). Based on the discussion above, the reaction behavior of toluene with methanol over the silanol nests was generalized in Scheme 1. The deep toluene alkylation with methanol could be promoted over the Brønsted acid sites with strong acidity, which accelerated the aromatic cycle and olefin cycle to form ethylene and propylene. Thus, the MTH reaction was also promoted because of the increased participation of methanol in intensified dual cycles, which promoted the formation of light alkene. In contrast, the weak acidity of silanol nests inhibited the deep alkylation, which correspondingly decreased MTH reaction based dual cycles and promoted the methanol utilization in the alkylation process. To confirm the key role of the silanol nests in the toluene conversion, NaDA1000 and HDA1000-R were synthesized according to the reported work (Fig S7, S8) [42]. As shown in Fig. 10, the toluene conversion and PX selectivity could reach 27.7% and 37.5%, which was obviously higher than 26% toluene conversion and 29.7% of PX selectivity of HDA1000-R. This directly suggested that the silanol nests with weak acidity could present a better catalytic role in the toluene conversion and PX formation than Brønsted acid sites with strong acidity. This effective roles of silanol nests on selective alkylation could also be reflected by decreased C9+ aromatics selectivity and the increased fraction of methanol for xylene. C9+ aromatics selectivity was 12.8% over NaDA1000, which was lower than 14.5% of HDA1000-R (Fig. 10c). The fraction of methanol for xylene reached 47.7% over NaDA1000, obviously higher than 40% of HDA1000-R. The role of silanol nests in the toluene methylation with methanol was further characterized by in situ DRIFTS ( Fig. 11). For H1000, the bands of C-H stretching vibration region of the methyl groups (2969 cm−1, 2925 cm−1 and 2856 cm−1) and the bands of C-H stretching vibration region of olefinic cations (3122 cm−1) were strengthened clearly, indicating the formation of alkene species after few minutes of reaction [33,43]. The bands of C-O stretching vibrations of methanol (1170 cm−1,1060 cm−1) and the negative bands of the interaction of methanol species with Brønsted acid sites (3600 cm−1) also appeared, suggesting the intense MTH reaction over Brønsted acid sites [33,40,44]. In addition, the appeared bands of C-H stretching vibrations of the benzene ring (3012 cm−1) was later than the C-H stretching vibrations of alkene species, indicating that the toluene substitution rate was slower than the alkene formation rate over Brønsted acid sites [40,45,46]. Compared with H1000, the rate of MTH reaction was significantly decreased over HDA1000 with weak acidic silanol nest groups. This can be supported by the decrease in formation rate of C-H of olefinic cations and the absence of C-O stretching vibrations bands of methanol. Meanwhile, the bands of unsaturated bonds of the benzene ring (1610 cm−1) appeared, which might be described to the adsorption of toluene [24,44,46]. The decreased MTH reaction and the adsorption of toluene could have a positive effect on toluene methylation with methanol. As for HS-1, low intensity of adsorption bands for olefinic cations and obvious bands of unsaturated bonds of benzene ring were found, suggesting the weakened MTH reaction and the enhanced absorbed toluene over silanol nests [47]. This also reflected that the positive effects of silanol nests on the alkylation of toluene with methanol. These results were consistent with the activity test results. According to the above results, the reaction pathway of toluene methylation with methanol could be inferred. For H1000, methanol could be preferentially absorbed on Brønsted acid sites and formed methoxonium ion. Afterwards, as-formed methoxonium ions can react with toluene to form xylene. However, because of the preferential occupation of these acid sites by methanol, the adsorption of toluene on Brønsted acid sites was weak, which decreased the toluene conversion. The absorbed methanol over Brønsted acid sites could be converted into light hydrocarbons. In addition, C9+ aromatics could also be formed, which accelerated carbon deposition. In contrast, the methanol adsorption was decreased over HDA1000 with silanol nests, which effectively reduced MTH reaction for the formation of light hydrocarbons. More importantly, the enhanced adsorption of toluene was observed over HDA1000, which increased toluene conversion with methanol and correspondingly suppressed the conversion of methanol to light hydrocarbons. The reaction process mentioned above is consistent with step-wise mechanism of toluene alkylation with methanol found in previous reports [48]. 3.5 To improve PX selectivity by increasing crystal size of dealuminated HZSM-5 As shown in Fig. S9, the large crystal size of HZSM-5 was synthesized by shortening aging time. As shown in Fig. 12, the toluene conversion and PX selectivity over parent H1000-L were only 25.9% and 27.6% respectively, which can be related to its strong acidity (Fig S10 and Table 6). In contrast, an increase in selective alkylation of methanol and toluene could be found for the dealuminated HDA1000-L with silanol nests (Fig. S11). Toluene conversion and PX selectivity could reach 26.8% and 65.5%, respectively. Importantly, the PX selectivity of HDA1000-L was higher than 36.1% of HDA1000 with the size of 2 µm, indicating the positive effects of the increased diffusion barrier in the micropores of large size of crystals (Table 6) [49]. As a result, the space-time yield of PX over HDA1000-L increased to 501.1 mg·gcat −1·h−1, higher than 337.8 mg·gcat −1·h−1 of HDA1000 (Table 6). However, the damage of micropores during dealumination also leads to a negative effect on the catalytic stability of HZSM-5 with large crystals (Fig. S1). 4 Conclusions In this work, high density of silanol nests were created through dealumination over a high SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5. Textural properties results showed that dealumination treatment slightly damaged the framework of zeolite. The acidity of HZSM-5 was decreased significantly because the removal of framework Al located at the straight 10-MR channels as characterized by NH3-TPD, Py-FTIR, and 27Al MAS NMR. Especially, 1H MAS NMR and OH-FTIR suggested that silanol nests with hydrogen bonds were created with a decrease of Brønsted acid sites. The catalytic performance demonstrated that selective alkylation and toluene conversion was enhanced obviously, and the alkylation efficiency and toluene conversion could reach 65.3% and 31.3% over HDA1000, respectively. This was attributed to the weakened double-cycle processes due to the decreased deep alkylation and light hydrocarbons formation. Consistent with the performance evaluation results, the single-factor experiments and in-situ DRIFTS also revealed that the formation rate of alkene was reduced and the adsorption of toluene was enhanced after the creation of silanol nests. Additionally, PX selectivity could reach 65.5% over HDA1000-L with 5 µm crystal size. This work provides new insight into the catalytic behavior of silanol nests in toluene alkylation with methanol, though it still takes a lot of effort to increase the selectivity of PX. coredata.dc:description: HZSM-5 catalysts with abundant silanol nests were fabricated by removing framework Al, which effectively promoted the selective alkylation of toluene with methanol by inhibiting the deep alkylation of aromatics to heavy aromatics and the conversion of methanol to light hydrocarbons. Correspondingly, the alkylation efficiency reached 65.3% at a toluene conversion of 31.3% over dealuminated HZSM-5, higher than the 55.2% efficiency and 28.0% conversion of parent zeolites, respectively. In situ DRIFTS and single-factor experimental clarified that toluene adsorption was enhanced and methanol to hydrocarbons was inhibited with the presence of silanol nests. Additionally, by increasing the crystal size of HZSM-5 with silanol nests from 2 to 5 µm, para-xylene selectivity was increased from 36.1% to 65.5% because of the enhanced diffusion barrier. The finding of the positive effect of the silanol nests on toluene alkylation can provide a solid fundamental basis for the rational design of catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Creation of silanol nests on HZSM-5 catalyst to boost the alkylation of toluene with methanol for PX synthesis
